questions.question_text: A technician is alerted to a virus on a PC. The technician isolates the PC from the network. After verifying there are no other infected PCs on the network, which of the following is the SAFEST method for the technician to use to clean the infected PC?

discussion.content: I agree with the answer b/c according to Professor Messer, the best thing to do is a clean install if possible!
Reimaging or "new OP system" clears out everything thus is the "SAFTEST" COMPTIA exam has a lot of "KEYWORD" type of questions

choices.B: Use System Restore to bring the PC back to a previous restore point
choices.D: Download another antivirus software that will quarantine the virus
choices.C: Reimage the computer and update it with all the latest patches
choices.A: Download and apply the security patch that addresses the vulnerability that was exploited

questions.question_text: A network administrator audited applications on a user's desktop and noticed a program used to sync a mobile device to the desktop's calendar. To ensure corporate data is not exchanged to cloud servers, which of the following mobile security methods should be implemented?

discussion.content: Nowhere in Comptia is Sandbox environments mentioned..... I thought it would be Device encryption

Trick question. I had to think about for a while.
could be B
but sandbox sound even better. A sandbox box is a containerised isolated environment. An example of this is Microsoft Intune company portal. Intune is Microsoft cloud(some else's datacentre)based mobile device management platform. The company portal app(ios/andriod) is "sandboxed" from rest of the mobile environment. Another specific example is virtualization, when you run a Virtual machine it's "sandboxed" from other virtual machines or host(unless networked). In terms of security it's mainly used as a test environment, for example you can execute a virus in a sandbox environment and it will not affect rest of the host.

comments.content: So it could be sandbox, if the admin believes the program is a malicious software that needs to be isolated in a sandbox environment so that it run without affecting the rest of the network or hosts...

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Sandboxing protects "live" servers and their data, vetted source code distributions, and other collections of code, data, and/or content, proprietary or public, from changes that could be damaging to a mission-critical system or which could simply be difficult to revert, regardless of the intent of the author of those changes.

Since the question is stating " To ensure corporate data is not exchanged to the cloud servers" I would pick D.
if it says encrypt data then i will choose that, but the option says device encryption its not the right one. maybe another question that doesn't have any points.
A seems the correct answer to me but could be wrong any idea?
This is probably a psychometric question, on the exam but not marked.

comments.content: I think psychologists should stop using us as guinea pigs.lol

discussion.content: A is the best answer to me
can anyone explain this to me ? I feel B is good choice

comments.content: Seriously? Do you know what a sandbox does?
What does sandbox environments have to do with security? The closest answer is B but none of these are good.
Device encryption has nothing to do with meeting this criteria: "To ensure corporate data is not exchanged to cloud servers"

discussion.content: so i have to assume that the laptop is upgraded or new or whatever, ok!ðŸ˜…ðŸ˜†

choices.C: The laptop's hard drive was formatted with FAT32 during the OS installation
choices.B: The laptop was not joined to the domain when the OS was installed
choices.D: The OS was not installed with the correct drivers for the laptop's input devices
choices.A: The administrator account was disabled during the installation of the OS

questions.question_text: Joe, a user, is unable to log into a laptop using his proper network credentials because of an incorrect username or password. However, Joe is able to log in without issue to a coworker's PC using his credentials. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the issue?

discussion.content: what's the difference between system image recovery and system restore

comments.content:
system image recovery: recover windows using a specific system image file
System restore: use restore point recorded in your PC to restore windows
 so, first need to perform system restore if it doesn't work, then you can test with system image recovery

choices.A: Go back to the previous build

questions.question_text:
A customer's computer was turned off overnight. When the customer restarts the computer, an advanced startup menu is displayed. The startup repair option is unsuccessful and causes the computer to reboot repeatedly until the advanced startup screen reappears. Which of the following should a technician attempt
FIRST?

choices.C: Navigate to the corporate intranet page and use hyperlinks to access the fileshare
choices.A: Navigate to the VPN profile in the device settings, delete the pre-shared key, and restart the device
choices.D: Instruct Ann to disable TLS 1.0 in the device settings
choices.B: Instruct Ann to open the company's MDM application to ensure proper functionality

questions.question_text: Ann, an employee, has been trying to use a company-issued mobile device to access an internal fileshare while traveling abroad. She restarted the device due to a mobile OS update, but she is now unable to access company information. Ann calls the help desk for assistance, and a technician verifies she can make calls and access websites. Which of the following should the technician suggest NEXT to try to fix the issue?

discussion.content: Can someone clarify? Is the concept here that her IP address changed and since pre shared keys are bound to IP addresses in many cases for VPNs, she needs to remove the prior key and restart the device for MDM to allocate a new pre shared key?
